column2: VOLUME I

column2: CHAPTER I
column3: CHAPTER one

column2: Emma Woodhouse, handsome, clever, and rich, with a comfortable home and happy disposition, seemed to unite some of the best blessings of existence; and had lived nearly twenty-one years in the world with very little to distress or vex her.
column3: Emma Woodhouse, handsome, clever, and rich, with a comfortable home and happy disposition, seemed to unite some of the best blessings of existence; and had lived nearly twenty one years in the world with very little to distress or vex her.

column2: She was the youngest of the two daughters of a most affectionate, indulgent father; and had, in consequence of her sister's marriage, been mistress of his house from a very early period.
column3: She was the youngest of the two daughters of a most affectionate, indulgent father; and had, in consequence of her sister's marriage, been mistress of his house from a very early period.

column2: Her mother had died too long ago for her to have more than an indistinct remembrance of her caresses; and her place had been supplied by an excellent woman as governess, who had fallen little short of a mother in affection.
column3: Her mother had died too long ago for her to have more than an indistinct remembrance of her caresses; and her place had been supplied by an excellent woman as governess, who had fallen little short of a mother in affection.

column2: Sixteen years had Miss Taylor been in Mr. Woodhouse's family, less as a governess than a friend, very fond of both daughters, but particularly of Emma.
column3: Sixteen years had Miss Taylor been in mr Woodhouse's family, less as a governess than a friend, very fond of both daughters, but particularly of Emma.

column2: Between _them_ it was more the intimacy of sisters.
column3: Between underscore them underscore it was more the intimacy of sisters.

column2: Even before Miss Taylor had ceased to hold the nominal office of governess, the mildness of her temper had hardly allowed her to impose any restraint; and the shadow of authority being now long passed away, they had been living together as friend and friend very mutually attached, and Emma doing just what she liked; highly esteeming Miss Taylor's judgment, but directed chiefly by her own.
column3: Even before Miss Taylor had ceased to hold the nominal office of governess, the mildness of her temper had hardly allowed her to impose any restraint; and the shadow of authority being now long passed away, they had been living together as friend and friend very mutually attached, and Emma doing just what she liked; highly esteeming Miss Taylor's judgment, but directed chiefly by her own.

column2: The real evils, indeed, of Emma's situation were the power of having rather too much her own way, and a disposition to think a little too well of herself; these were the disadvantages which threatened alloy to her many enjoyments.
column3: The real evils, indeed, of Emma's situation were the power of having rather too much her own way, and a disposition to think a little too well of herself; these were the disadvantages which threatened alloy to her many enjoyments.

column2: The danger, however, was at present so unperceived, that they did not by any means rank as misfortunes with her.
column3: The danger, however, was at present so unperceived, that they did not by any means rank as misfortunes with her.

column2: Sorrow came--a gentle sorrow--but not at all in the shape of any disagreeable consciousness.--Miss Taylor married.
column3: Sorrow came-a gentle sorrow-but not at all in the shape of any disagreeable consciousness.--Miss Taylor married.

column2: It was Miss Taylor's loss which first brought grief.
column3: It was Miss Taylor's loss which first brought grief.

column2: It was on the wedding-day of this beloved friend that Emma first sat in mournful thought of any continuance.
column3: It was on the wedding day of this beloved friend that Emma first sat in mournful thought of any continuance.

column2: The wedding over, and the bride-people gone, her father and herself were left to dine together, with no prospect of a third to cheer a long evening.
column3: The wedding over, and the bride people gone, her father and herself were left to dine together, with no prospect of a third to cheer a long evening.

column2: Her father composed himself to sleep after dinner, as usual, and she had then only to sit and think of what she had lost.
column3: Her father composed himself to sleep after dinner, as usual, and she had then only to sit and think of what she had lost.

column2: The event had every promise of happiness for her friend.
column3: The event had every promise of happiness for her friend.

column2: Mr. Weston was a man of unexceptionable character, easy fortune, suitable age, and pleasant manners; and there was some satisfaction in considering with what self-denying, generous friendship she had always wished and promoted the match; but it was a black morning's work for her.
column3: mr Weston was a man of unexceptionable character, easy fortune, suitable age, and pleasant manners; and there was some satisfaction in considering with what self denying, generous friendship she had always wished and promoted the match; but it was a black morning's work for her.

column2: The want of Miss Taylor would be felt every hour of every day.
column3: The want of Miss Taylor would be felt every hour of every day.

column2: She recalled her past kindness--the kindness, the affection of sixteen years--how she had taught and how she had played with her from five years old--how she had devoted all her powers to attach and amuse her in health--and how nursed her through the various illnesses of childhood.
column3: She recalled her past kindness-the kindness, the affection of sixteen years-how she had taught and how she had played with her from five years old-how she had devoted all her powers to attach and amuse her in health-and how nursed her through the various illnesses of childhood.

column2: A large debt of gratitude was owing here; but the intercourse of the last seven years, the equal footing and perfect unreserve which had soon followed Isabella's marriage, on their being left to each other, was yet a dearer, tenderer recollection.
column3: A large debt of gratitude was owing here; but the intercourse of the last seven years, the equal footing and perfect unreserve which had soon followed Isabella's marriage, on their being left to each other, was yet a dearer, tenderer recollection.

column2: She had been a friend and companion such as few possessed: intelligent, well-informed, useful, gentle, knowing all the ways of the family, interested in all its concerns, and peculiarly interested in herself, in every pleasure, every scheme of hers--one to whom she could speak every thought as it arose, and who had such an affection for her as could never find fault.
column3: She had been a friend and companion such as few possessed: intelligent, well informed, useful, gentle, knowing all the ways of the family, interested in all its concerns, and peculiarly interested in herself, in every pleasure, every scheme of hers-one to whom she could speak every thought as it arose, and who had such an affection for her as could never find fault.

column2: How was she to bear the change?--It was true that her friend was going only half a mile from them; but Emma was aware that great must be the difference between a Mrs. Weston, only half a mile from them, and a Miss Taylor in the house; and with all her advantages, natural and domestic, she was now in great danger of suffering from intellectual solitude.
column3: How was she to bear the change?--It was true that her friend was going only half a mile from them; but Emma was aware that great must be the difference between a mrs Weston, only half a mile from them, and a Miss Taylor in the house; and with all her advantages, natural and domestic, she was now in great danger of suffering from intellectual solitude.

column2: She dearly loved her father, but he was no companion for her.
column3: She dearly loved her father, but he was no companion for her.

column2: He could not meet her in conversation, rational or playful.
column3: He could not meet her in conversation, rational or playful.

column2: The evil of the actual disparity in their ages (and Mr. Woodhouse had not married early) was much increased by his constitution and habits; for having been a valetudinarian all his life, without activity of mind or body, he was a much older man in ways than in years; and though everywhere beloved for the friendliness of his heart and his amiable temper, his talents could not have recommended him at any time.
column3: The evil of the actual disparity in their ages (and mr Woodhouse had not married early) was much increased by his constitution and habits; for having been a valetudinarian all his life, without activity of mind or body, he was a much older man in ways than in years; and though everywhere beloved for the friendliness of his heart and his amiable temper, his talents could not have recommended him at any time.

column2: Her sister, though comparatively but little removed by matrimony, being settled in London, only sixteen miles off, was much beyond her daily reach; and many a long October and November evening must be struggled through at Hartfield, before Christmas brought the next visit from Isabella and her husband, and their little children, to fill the house, and give her pleasant society again.
column3: Her sister, though comparatively but little removed by matrimony, being settled in London, only sixteen miles off, was much beyond her daily reach; and many a long October and November evening must be struggled through at Hartfield, before Christmas brought the next visit from Isabella and her husband, and their little children, to fill the house, and give her pleasant society again.

column2: Highbury, the large and populous village, almost amounting to a town, to which Hartfield, in spite of its separate lawn, and shrubberies, and name, did really belong, afforded her no equals.
column3: Highbury, the large and populous village, almost amounting to a town, to which Hartfield, in spite of its separate lawn, and shrubberies, and name, did really belong, afforded her no equals.

column2: The Woodhouses were first in consequence there.
column3: The Woodhouses were first in consequence there.

column2: All looked up to them.
column3: All looked up to them.

column2: She had many acquaintance in the place, for her father was universally civil, but not one among them who could be accepted in lieu of Miss Taylor for even half a day.
column3: She had many acquaintance in the place, for her father was universally civil, but not one among them who could be accepted in lieu of Miss Taylor for even half a day.

column2: It was a melancholy change; and Emma could not but sigh over it, and wish for impossible things, till her father awoke, and made it necessary to be cheerful.
column3: It was a melancholy change; and Emma could not but sigh over it, and wish for impossible things, till her father awoke, and made it necessary to be cheerful.

column2: His spirits required support.
column3: His spirits required support.

column2: He was a nervous man, easily depressed; fond of every body that he was used to, and hating to part with them; hating change of every kind.
column3: He was a nervous man, easily depressed; fond of every body that he was used to, and hating to part with them; hating change of every kind.

column2: Matrimony, as the origin of change, was always disagreeable; and he was by no means yet reconciled to his own daughter's marrying, nor could ever speak of her but with compassion, though it had been entirely a match of affection, when he was now obliged to part with Miss Taylor too; and from his habits of gentle selfishness, and of being never able to suppose that other people could feel differently from himself, he was very much disposed to think Miss Taylor had done as sad a thing for herself as for them, and would have been a great deal happier if she had spent all the rest of her life at Hartfield.
column3: Matrimony, as the origin of change, was always disagreeable; and he was by no means yet reconciled to his own daughter's marrying, nor could ever speak of her but with compassion, though it had been entirely a match of affection, when he was now obliged to part with Miss Taylor too; and from his habits of gentle selfishness, and of being never able to suppose that other people could feel differently from himself, he was very much disposed to think Miss Taylor had done as sad a thing for herself as for them, and would have been a great deal happier if she had spent all the rest of her life at Hartfield.

column2: Emma smiled and chatted as cheerfully as she could, to keep him from such thoughts; but when tea came, it was impossible for him not to say exactly as he had said at dinner,
column3: Emma smiled and chatted as cheerfully as she could, to keep him from such thoughts; but when tea came, it was impossible for him not to say exactly as he had said at dinner,

column2: What a pity it is that Mr. Weston ever thought of her!"
column3: What a pity it is that mr Weston ever thought of her!"

column2: Mr. Weston is such a good-humoured, pleasant, excellent man, that he thoroughly deserves a good wife;--and you would not have had Miss Taylor live with us for ever, and bear all my odd humours, when she might have a house of her own?"
column3: mr Weston is such a good humoured, pleasant, excellent man, that he thoroughly deserves a good wife;--and you would not have had Miss Taylor live with us for ever, and bear all my odd humours, when she might have a house of her own?"

column2: A house of her own!--But where is the advantage of a house of her own? This is three times as large.--And you have never any odd humours, my dear.

column2: It was very lucky, for I would not have had poor James think himself slighted upon any account; and I am sure she will make a very good servant: she is a civil, pretty-spoken girl; I have a great opinion of her.

column2: Whenever I see her, she always curtseys and asks me how I do, in a very pretty manner; and when you have had her here to do needlework, I observe she always turns the lock of the door the right way and never bangs it.

column2: I am sure she will be an excellent servant; and it will be a great comfort to poor Miss Taylor to have somebody about her that she is used to see.
column3: I am sure she will be an excellent servant; and it will be a great comfort to poor Miss Taylor to have somebody about her that she is used to see.

column2: Whenever James goes over to see his daughter, you know, she will be hearing of us.

column2: Emma spared no exertions to maintain this happier flow of ideas, and hoped, by the help of backgammon, to get her father tolerably through the evening, and be attacked by no regrets but her own.

column2: Mr. Knightley, a sensible man about seven or eight-and-thirty, was not only a very old and intimate friend of the family, but particularly connected with it, as the elder brother of Isabella's husband.
column3: mr Knightley, a sensible man about seven or eight and thirty, was not only a very old and intimate friend of the family, but particularly connected with it, as the elder brother of Isabella's husband.

column2: He lived about a mile from Highbury, was a frequent visitor, and always welcome, and at this time more welcome than usual, as coming directly from their mutual connexions in London.

column2: It was a happy circumstance, and animated Mr. Woodhouse for some time.

column2: Mr. Knightley had a cheerful manner, which always did him good; and his many inquiries after "poor Isabella" and her children were answered most satisfactorily.

column2: When this was over, Mr. Woodhouse gratefully observed, "It is very kind of you, Mr. Knightley, to come out at this late hour to call upon us.

column2: I am afraid you must have had a shocking walk."

Ever since the day-about four years ago-that Miss Taylor and I met with him in Broadway Lane, when, because it began to drizzle, he darted away with so much gallantry, and borrowed two umbrellas for us from Farmer Mitchell's, I made up my mind on the subject.
column3: true

column2: I planned the match from that hour; and when such success has blessed me in this instance, dear papa, you cannot think that I shall leave off match-making."
column3: I planned the match from that hour; and when such success has blessed me in this instance, dear papa, you cannot think that I shall leave off match making."

column2: I do not understand what you mean by 'success,' said Mr. Knightley. "Success supposes endeavour.
column3: I do not understand what you mean by 'success,' said mr Knightley. "Success supposes endeavour.

column2: Your time has been properly and delicately spent, if you have been endeavouring for the last four years to bring about this marriage.
column3: Your time has been properly and delicately spent, if you have been endeavouring for the last four years to bring about this marriage.

column2: A worthy employment for a young lady's mind!
column3: A worthy employment for a young lady's mind!

column2: But if, which I rather imagine, your making the match, as you call it, means only your planning it, your saying to yourself one idle day, 'I think it would be a very good thing for Miss Taylor if Mr. Weston were to marry her,' and saying it again to yourself every now and then afterwards, why do you talk of success?
column3: But if, which I rather imagine, your making the match, as you call it, means only your planning it, your saying to yourself one idle day, 'I think it would be a very good thing for Miss Taylor if mr Weston were to marry her,' and saying it again to yourself every now and then afterwards, why do you talk of success?

column2: Where is your merit?
column3: Where is your merit?

column2: What are you proud of?
column3: What are you proud of?

column2: You made a lucky guess; and _that_ is all that can be said."
column3: You made a lucky guess; and underscore that underscore is all that can be said."

column2: And have you never known the pleasure and triumph of a lucky guess?--I pity you.--I thought you cleverer--for, depend upon it a lucky guess is never merely luck.	And have you never known the pleasure and triumph of a lucky guess?--I pity you.--I thought you cleverer-for, depend upon it a lucky guess is never merely luck.
column3: false

column2: There is always some talent in it.
column3: There is always some talent in it.

column2: And as to my poor word 'success,' which you quarrel with, I do not know that I am so entirely without any claim to it.
column3: And as to my poor word 'success,' which you quarrel with, I do not know that I am so entirely without any claim to it.

column2: You have drawn two pretty pictures; but I think there may be a third--a something between the do-nothing and the do-all.
column3: You have drawn two pretty pictures; but I think there may be a third-a something between the do nothing and the do all.

column2: If I had not promoted Mr. Weston's visits here, and given many little encouragements, and smoothed many little matters, it might not have come to any thing after all.
column3: If I had not promoted mr Weston's visits here, and given many little encouragements, and smoothed many little matters, it might not have come to any thing after all.

column2: I think you must know Hartfield enough to comprehend that."
column3: I think you must know Hartfield enough to comprehend that."

column2: A straightforward, open-hearted man like Weston, and a rational, unaffected woman like Miss Taylor, may be safely left to manage their own concerns.	A straightforward, open hearted man like Weston, and a rational, unaffected woman like Miss Taylor, may be safely left to manage their own concerns.
column3: true

column2: You are more likely to have done harm to yourself, than good to them, by interference."
column3: You are more likely to have done harm to yourself, than good to them, by interference."

column2: Emma never thinks of herself, if she can do good to others, rejoined Mr. Woodhouse, understanding but in part.
column3: Emma never thinks of herself, if she can do good to others, rejoined mr Woodhouse, understanding but in part.

column2: But, my dear, pray do not make any more matches; they are silly things, and break up one's family circle grievously.
column3: But, my dear, pray do not make any more matches; they are silly things, and break up one's family circle grievously.

column2: Only one more, papa; only for Mr. Elton.	Only one more, papa; only for mr Elton.
column3: true

column2: Poor Mr. Elton!
column3: Poor mr Elton!

column2: You like Mr. Elton, papa,--I must look about for a wife for him.
column3: You like mr Elton, papa,--I must look about for a wife for him.

column2: There is nobody in Highbury who deserves him--and he has been here a whole year, and has fitted up his house so comfortably, that it would be a shame to have him single any longer--and I thought when he was joining their hands to-day, he looked so very much as if he would like to have the same kind office done for him!
column3: There is nobody in Highbury who deserves him-and he has been here a whole year, and has fitted up his house so comfortably, that it would be a shame to have him single any longer-and I thought when he was joining their hands to day, he looked so very much as if he would like to have the same kind office done for him!

column2: I think very well of Mr. Elton, and this is the only way I have of doing him a service."
column3: I think very well of mr Elton, and this is the only way I have of doing him a service."

column2: Mr. Elton is a very pretty young man, to be sure, and a very good young man, and I have a great regard for him.	mr Elton is a very pretty young man, to be sure, and a very good young man, and I have a great regard for him.
column3: false

column2: But if you want to shew him any attention, my dear, ask him to come and dine with us some day.
column3: But if you want to shew him any attention, my dear, ask him to come and dine with us some day.

column2: That will be a much better thing.
column3: That will be a much better thing.

column2: I dare say Mr. Knightley will be so kind as to meet him."
column3: I dare say mr Knightley will be so kind as to meet him."

column2: With a great deal of pleasure, sir, at any time, said Mr. Knightley, laughing, "and I agree with you entirely, that it will be a much better thing.
column3: With a great deal of pleasure, sir, at any time, said mr Knightley, laughing, "and I agree with you entirely, that it will be a much better thing.

column2: Invite him to dinner, Emma, and help him to the best of the fish and the chicken, but leave him to chuse his own wife.
column3: Invite him to dinner, Emma, and help him to the best of the fish and the chicken, but leave him to chuse his own wife.

column2: Depend upon it, a man of six or seven-and-twenty can take care of himself."
column3: Depend upon it, a man of six or seven and twenty can take care of himself."
